regulation_detail: Port of Singapore is the world's largest transhipment hub.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Port of Singapore is operated by PSA Singapore.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Port of Singapore features 55 berths across multiple terminals.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Operational flow in Singapore is highly optimized for transhipment, emphasizing efficient container transfer between vessels.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Port of Singapore leverages digital tools for vessel schedules, container tracking, and online payments.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Shanghai Port is the world's busiest container port.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Shanghai Port encompasses key terminal areas including Yangshan, Waigaoqiao, and Wusong.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: All vessels arriving at Singapore Port are subject to general declaration requirements.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: General declarations for Singapore Port must be submitted to the Marine Licensing and Permits department (MLP) via the digitalPORT@SGTM platform.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: General declaration for Singapore Port must be submitted within 24 hours of arrival.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Singapore Port General Declaration requires vessel's arrival date/time, last port of call, location upon arrival, master's name, crew/passenger numbers, total cargo on board.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: For vessels calling at Singapore for the first time, 'Application of Vessel Record Creation' is mandatory via digitalPORT@SGTM.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: For Vessel Record Creation in Singapore, Certificate of Registry and International Tonnage Certificate must be submitted via digitalPORT@SGTM.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Single-hulled tankers calling at Singapore must submit a pre-arrival declaration to the Port Master at least 24 hours before arrival.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Commonly required import documents at Shanghai Port include: Customs Export Declaration, Customs Power of Attorney, Commercial Invoice, Bill of Lading (B/L), Packing List (P/L), Certificate of Origin.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Commonly required export documents at Shanghai Port include: Customs Export Declaration, Customs Power of Attorney, Commercial Invoice, Contract, Packing List (P/L), Solas Certificate (VGM).
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Singapore utilizes TradeNet®, a national single window for all trade declarations.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: TradeNet® allows businesses in Singapore to fulfill import, export, and transhipment regulatory requirements electronically.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Access to TradeNet® in Singapore for customs procedures requires Singpass for secure login.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Essential customs procedures in Singapore include registering as a trader with ACRA and activating a Customs Account.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Permit applications for importing goods into Singapore, including containerized cargo, must be submitted via TradeNet®.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Permit applications via TradeNet® for importing goods into Singapore require details such as container number and shipper seal number.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Customs procedures in Shanghai Port encompass Enterprise Administration, Customs Clearance Administration, Cargo Control, Health and Quarantine, Animal/Plant Quarantine, Food Safety, Commodity Inspection.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Import customs clearance process at Shanghai Port involves: foreign information implementation, manifest query, import declaration submission, tax payment, inspection (if required), B/L switching (potential), delivery arrangement, destination inspection (potential).
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Shanghai Port experienced difficulties in receiving deliveries due to stringent COVID-19 policies related to potential parcel contamination.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Volatility of freight rates from Shanghai adds complexity to shipping costs and planning.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Inconsistent customs requirements across different customs offices in China (including Shanghai) pose challenges for exporters.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Language barriers can pose difficulties for international stakeholders navigating documentation processes at Shanghai Port.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Implementation of Maritime Single Window in Singapore faced hurdles in stakeholder coordination, legal/regulatory adaptation, data standardization, technical integration, data privacy/security, training.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Adoption of PORTNET digital platform in Singapore faced resistance due to integration difficulties and data security concerns.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: China's customs regulations (Shanghai) are part of a comprehensive state-controlled system, potentially more bureaucratic compared to EU.
source_document: Comparative Report
source_section: 7. Key Differences in Regulatory Environments and Operational Practices

regulation_detail: Singapore's regulatory environment is often perceived as highly efficient and business-friendly.
source_document: Comparative Report
source_section: 7. Key Differences in Regulatory Environments and Operational Practices

regulation_detail: Singapore is leading in digitalization through early adoption and effective implementation of TradeNet® (national single window).
source_document: Comparative Report
source_section: 7. Key Differences in Regulatory Environments and Operational Practices

regulation_detail: European ports (Rotterdam, Hamburg) have a longer history of automation in container handling compared to Asian ports (Shanghai, Singapore).
source_document: Comparative Report
source_section: 7. Key Differences in Regulatory Environments and Operational Practices

regulation_detail: Hamburg boasts Europe's largest rail port, highlighting strong rail connections to its hinterland.
source_document: Comparative Report
source_section: 7. Key Differences in Regulatory Environments and Operational Practices

regulation_detail: Berths at the Port of Singapore are strategically located across multiple terminals.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Port of Singapore functions as an integrated and seamless facility.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Port of Singapore offers digital access to vessel schedules.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Port of Singapore offers digital container tracking services.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Port of Singapore offers online payment options for port services.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Singapore Port's focus on digitalization aims to enhance efficiency and transparency.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Singapore Port General Declaration requires provision of vessel's arrival date.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Singapore Port General Declaration requires provision of vessel's arrival time.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Singapore Port General Declaration requires provision of vessel's last port of call.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Singapore Port General Declaration requires provision of vessel's location upon arrival.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Singapore Port General Declaration requires provision of vessel's master's name.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Singapore Port General Declaration requires provision of number of crew on board.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Singapore Port General Declaration requires provision of number of passengers on board.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Singapore Port General Declaration requires provision of total cargo on board.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Trader registration in Singapore customs procedures requires registration with the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA).
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Trader registration in Singapore customs procedures requires activation of a Customs Account.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Import permit applications via TradeNet® for containerized cargo in Singapore require provision of the container number.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Import permit applications via TradeNet® for containerized cargo in Singapore require provision of the shipper seal number.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Implementation of Maritime Single Window in Singapore faced coordination challenges among various stakeholders.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Implementation of Maritime Single Window in Singapore required adaptation of legal and regulatory frameworks.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Implementation of Maritime Single Window in Singapore faced challenges in data standardization.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Implementation of Maritime Single Window in Singapore faced challenges in technical integration with existing systems.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Implementation of Maritime Single Window in Singapore raised data privacy and security concerns.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Implementation of Maritime Single Window in Singapore required providing adequate training to users.
source_document: Comparative Report

regulation_detail: Singapore's business-friendly regulatory environment is evident in its effective implementation of TradeNet®.
source_document: Comparative Report
source_section: 7. Key Differences in Regulatory Environments and Operational Practices

regulation_detail: Single Hulled Tankers (SHTs) must submit a pre-arrival declaration to the Port Master.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Pre-arrival Declaration for Single Hulled Tankers

regulation_detail: Pre-arrival declaration for Single Hulled Tankers must be submitted at least 24 hours before arrival to Singapore.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Pre-arrival Declaration for Single Hulled Tankers

regulation_detail: Pre-arrival declaration for Single Hulled Tankers applies to SHTs weighing 5000 deadweight tons (DWT) and above.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Pre-arrival Declaration for Single Hulled Tankers

regulation_detail: Pre-arrival declaration for SHTs can be submitted immediately on departure from a nearby port with less than 24 hours steaming time to Singapore.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Pre-arrival Declaration for Single Hulled Tankers

regulation_detail: Pre-arrival Declaration form for SHTs must be sent to the Port Master by fax or telex.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Pre-arrival Declaration for Single Hulled Tankers

regulation_detail: Vessels not complying with MARPOL Convention on SHTs may be denied entry into Singapore port.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Pre-arrival Declaration for Single Hulled Tankers

regulation_detail: Vessels not complying with MARPOL Convention on SHTs may be detained if already in Singapore port.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Pre-arrival Declaration for Single Hulled Tankers

regulation_detail: Notification of Arrival (NOA) procedures apply to passenger vessels or vessels of 300 GT or more.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Pre-arrival Notification and Notification of Arrival (NOA) Procedures

regulation_detail: Notification of Arrival (NOA) must be submitted at least 12 hours prior to vessel's arrival in Singapore.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Pre-arrival Notification and Notification of Arrival (NOA) Procedures

regulation_detail: NOA must be submitted once vessel departs if coming from a nearby port with less than 12 hours steaming time to Singapore.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Pre-arrival Notification and Notification of Arrival (NOA) Procedures

regulation_subcategory: Notification of Arrival Timing - Hazardous Cargo
regulation_detail: NOA must be submitted at least 24 hours in advance if vessel carries hazardous and noxious substances in bulk.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Pre-arrival Notification and Notification of Arrival (NOA) Procedures

regulation_subcategory: Notification of Arrival - Hazardous Cargo Details
regulation_detail: NOA for hazardous cargo must contain cargo details according to Port Marine Circular No. 15 of 1998.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Pre-arrival Notification and Notification of Arrival (NOA) Procedures

regulation_detail: Notification of Arrival (NOA) report must be sent in the defined reporting format.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Pre-arrival Notification and Notification of Arrival (NOA) Procedures

regulation_detail: Vessels arriving with oil or noxious liquid substance residues must declare quantity and content in NOA.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Pre-arrival Notification and Notification of Arrival (NOA) Procedures

regulation_detail: Vessels discharging oil/noxious liquid substance residues in port must provide slop/sludge details in NOA item 11.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Pre-arrival Notification and Notification of Arrival (NOA) Procedures

regulation_detail: NOA must include details of arrangement with approved reception facility for discharge of oil/noxious liquid substance residues.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Pre-arrival Notification and Notification of Arrival (NOA) Procedures

regulation_detail: Notification of Arrival (NOA) report can be sent to Port Master by email.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Pre-arrival Notification and Notification of Arrival (NOA) Procedures

regulation_detail: Notification of Arrival (NOA) report can be sent to Port Master by fax.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Pre-arrival Notification and Notification of Arrival (NOA) Procedures

regulation_detail: Notification of Arrival (NOA) report can be sent to Port Master by telex.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Pre-arrival Notification and Notification of Arrival (NOA) Procedures

regulation_detail: Confirmation of Arrival procedures apply to vessels of 300 GT or more, tugs with combined GT 300+, and passenger vessels.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore

regulation_detail: Confirmation of Arrival report must be made to VTIS by VHF radiotelephone.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore

regulation_detail: Confirmation of Arrival report to VTIS must be made when vessel is at specific reporting points (e.g., abeam Horsburgh lighthouse).
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Reporting points for Confirmation of Arrival

regulation_detail: Vessels approaching from East (South China Sea) report Confirmation of Arrival to VTIS East on VHF CH 10.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Reporting to VTIS East on VHF CH 10

regulation_detail: Vessels in TSS in Singapore Strait report Confirmation of Arrival to VTIS Central on VHF CH 14.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Reporting to VTIS Central on VHF CH 14

regulation_detail: Vessels approaching from West (Malacca Strait) report Confirmation of Arrival to VTIS West on VHF CH 73.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Reporting to VTIS West on VHF CH 73

regulation_detail: VHF Confirmation of Arrival report must contain Vessel's name.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: The VHF Confirmation of Arrival report must contain the following information

regulation_detail: VHF Confirmation of Arrival report must contain Vessel's call sign.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: The VHF Confirmation of Arrival report must contain the following information

regulation_detail: VHF Confirmation of Arrival report must contain Vessel's present location (referenced to reporting points).
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: The VHF Confirmation of Arrival report must contain the following information

regulation_subcategory: Confirmation of Arrival Information - Passenger Vessels
regulation_detail: VHF Confirmation of Arrival report for passenger vessels must contain number of passengers and crew.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: The VHF Confirmation of Arrival report must contain the following information

regulation_detail: VHF Confirmation of Arrival report must contain ETA at first destination in Port or pilot boarding ground name.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: The VHF Confirmation of Arrival report must contain the following information

regulation_detail: VHF Confirmation of Arrival report must contain Vessel's height if it differs from NOA report.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: The VHF Confirmation of Arrival report must contain the following information

regulation_detail: Port clearance from Singapore Port Master requires submission of Departure General Declaration.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore

regulation_detail: Departure General Declaration for Port Clearance must be submitted via digitalPORT@SGTM.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore

regulation_detail: For port stays <= 3 days, combined Arrival and Departure General Declaration can be submitted in Singapore.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore

regulation_detail: Departure General Declaration requires submission of Vessel Details, Purpose of call, Departure Details, Cargo, Passenger, Crew info.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore

regulation_detail: For first call vessels, Vessel Record Creation via digitalPORT@SGTM is required before Departure General Declaration.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore

regulation_detail: Vessel must ensure all statutory and mandatory certificates are in force when proceeding to sea from Singapore.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore

regulation_detail: Copies of required vessel certificates to be submitted to MLP via digitalPORT@SGTM for first call or changed status.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore

regulation_detail: Port Clearance Certificate (PCC) in Singapore is generated by the system through Electronic Port Clearance (EPC) system.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore

regulation_detail: Authenticity of Singapore PCC can be confirmed online by entering details from the certificate.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore

regulation_detail: Vessel must leave Singapore port within 48 hours of obtaining port clearance, or shorter period specified by Port Master.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Vessel to Leave Port within 48 hours

regulation_detail: Agent must return PCC to Port Master within 6 hours after expiry of 48-hour departure period.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Vessel to Leave Port within 48 hours

regulation_detail: Agent required to obtain a fresh PCC if vessel does not leave port within 48 hours and as required by Port Master.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Vessel to Leave Port within 48 hours

regulation_detail: Vessels arrested by Sheriff of High Court will not be granted port clearance in Singapore.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Vessels that will not be granted Port Clearance

regulation_detail: Vessels detained for MPA Act non-compliance will not be granted port clearance in Singapore.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Vessels that will not be granted Port Clearance

regulation_detail: Vessels of owners/masters failing to comply with MPA Act will not be granted port clearance in Singapore.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Vessels that will not be granted Port Clearance

regulation_detail: Vessels of owners/masters charged with MPA Act offense will not be granted port clearance in Singapore.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore
source_section: Vessels that will not be granted Port Clearance

regulation_detail: Shipping agencies can use Electronic Port Clearance (EPC) scheme to submit port clearance via digitalPORT@SGTM.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore

regulation_detail: EPC users declare vessels are properly crewed and have valid certificates when applying for port clearance.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore

regulation_detail: EPC users need not present original certificates to MLP for inspection before departure.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore

regulation_subcategory: Electronic Port Clearance (EPC) - Digital Certificate Submission
regulation_detail: EPC users submit certificate copies to MLP via digitalPORT@SGTM if MPA status expired/changed.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore

regulation_detail: EPC users no longer need to submit last port clearance certificate and departure crew/passenger lists to MLP.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore

regulation_detail: EPC users must retain vessel's last port clearance and departure crew/passenger lists for 3 months for audit.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore

regulation_detail: Wrongful declaration or failure to submit documents in EPC scheme may lead to prosecution action.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore

regulation_detail: To apply for EPC scheme, login to digitalPORT@SGTM and select 'Application for Electronic Port Clearance Scheme' function.
source_document: MPA - Vessels Arriving in Singapore

regulation_detail: "appointed officer" means a person authorised or appointed as an appointed officer under section 89A(1).
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "authorised pilot" means any person employed or authorised by the Authority to pilot vessels under section 62.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "Authority" means the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore established under section 4.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "beacon" means a prominent specially‑constructed object forming a conspicuous mark as a fixed aid to navigation.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "berthing master" means any person authorised under section 62(2)(b) to act as a berthing master.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "buoy" includes a floating object of any size, shape and colour which is moored to the seabed and serves as an aid to navigation or for other specific purposes.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "Chairperson" means the Chairperson of the Authority and includes any acting Chairperson of the Authority.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "Chief Executive" means the Chief Executive of the Authority, and includes any individual acting in that capacity.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "container" means a receptacle 6.1 metres or more in length equipped with corner castings to facilitate handling by mechanical equipment.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "dangerous cargoes" means such cargoes, whether packaged, carried in bulk packagings or in bulk, as may be prescribed.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "Deputy Chairperson" means the Deputy Chairperson of the Authority and includes any acting Deputy Chairperson of the Authority.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "Director of Marine" means the Director of Marine appointed under section 4 of the Merchant Shipping Act 1995.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "dock" means an artificial excavation or construction in which vessels can be placed for loading, unloading, fitting out or repairing and includes gridirons, slips, keel blocks, inclined planes and all machinery, works, fixtures and anything attached or pertaining thereto.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "dues" includes port dues, goods dues and pilotage dues levied under this Act but does not include rates.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "equipment" includes any appliance, apparatus, machinery, system or accessory used or intended to be used for the purposes of providing marine or port services and facilities.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "goods" includes dangerous cargoes, animals, carcases, baggage, containers and any other movable property of any kind and whether in a refrigerated form or otherwise.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "harbour craft" means any vessel which is used in the port for any purpose.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "lighthouse" means a distinctive structure on or off a coast exhibiting a major light designed to serve as an aid to navigation.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "marine services and facilities" means the towage and pilotage of vessels and the supply of water to vessels.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "master" includes every person, except a pilot, having command or charge of any vessel.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "member" means a member of the Authority.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "owner", in relation to any vessel, includes any part‑owner, charterer, operator, consignee or mortgagee in possession of the vessel or any duly authorised agent of any such person.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "passenger" has the meaning given by the Merchant Shipping Act 1995.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "pilot" means any person not belonging to a vessel who has the conduct of it.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "Pilotage Committee" means the Pilotage Committee appointed under section 66.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "pilotage district" means any area in the port declared under section 59 to be a pilotage district.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "port" means any place in Singapore and any navigable river or channel leading into a place declared to be a port under section 3.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "port dues" means dues levied in respect of a vessel for entering, using, leaving or plying in the port.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "Port Master" means the Port Master appointed under section 15 and includes any Deputy Port Master appointed under that section.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "port services and facilities" means port terminal services and facilities for the handling, storage and transportation of goods on land adjoining the foreshore of Singapore and for the handling of passengers carried by vessels.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "premises" includes messuages, houses, buildings, structures, lands, tenements, easements and hereditaments of any tenure, whether open or enclosed, whether built on or not, whether public or private, and whether maintained or not under statutory authority.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "public licence" means a licence granted under section 81 and “public licensee” is construed accordingly.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "rates" means any rates or charges leviable by the Authority under this Act and includes any toll or rent but does not include dues.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "regulations" means regulations made under this Act.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "seaman" means any person normally engaged on ship’s articles on any vessel going beyond the limits of the port, but does not include specified exclusions (masters, officers, probationers, non-seamen duties).
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "vehicle" has the meaning given by the Road Traffic Act 1961.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "vessel" includes any ship or boat or air‑cushioned vehicle or floating rig or platform used in any form of operations at sea.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: "wharf" includes a quay, pier, jetty, ramp or other landing place.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Authority may make regulations for regulating traffic and preventing/removing obstructions to navigation within port limits and approaches.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Authority may make regulations for conduct of inquiries into cases where damage caused to or by a vessel.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Authority may make regulations for regulating keeping or placing of private moorings or buoys.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Authority may make regulations for lights and signals in port and steps to avoid collisions.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Authority may make regulations for information to be supplied by masters/owners/agents for arriving/departing vessels.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Authority may regulate/control vessel use in territorial waters, activities in port waters, including towage, water/fuel supply, licensing.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Authority may permit/regulate/control landing and movement of foreign armed services personnel in port.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Authority may make regulations for keeping port waters/premises clean, preventing pollution (oil, filth, rubbish).
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Authority may make regulations for use/manning of harbour craft, licensing of harbour craft.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Authority may supervise/regulate/control all activities in port waters, licensing of activities.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Authority may regulate provision/maintenance of pontoons, moorings, berthing facilities, licensing thereof.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Authority may regulate provision/maintenance of beacons, lighthouses, buoys (not Authority-owned), licensing thereof.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Authority may prescribe competence standards for harbour craft officers/crew, examinations, licensing/certification.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Authority may regulate harbour craft construction, machinery, equipment, fittings, safety/firefighting appliances, surveys, certifications.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Authority may regulate navigation and anchoring/mooring of vessels carrying dangerous cargoes.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Authority may regulate utilizing, stowing, keeping dangerous cargoes on vessels, conveyance with other goods in port.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Authority may regulate/declare/define wharves/docks for goods landing/shipping.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Authority may regulate keeping free passages in port, along wharves/docks/moorings.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Authority may regulate information supply by masters/owners/agents for goods loaded/discharged at port wharves.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Authority may prohibit embarkation/disembarkation except at authorized places.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Authority may prohibit loading/discharging goods except at authorized wharves/docks (dutiable/non-dutiable goods distinctions).
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Authority may prohibit dangerous cargo loading/handling/discharging at wharves/docks deemed specially dangerous.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Contravention of port regulations may result in fine up to $20,000, imprisonment up to 6 months, or both; continuing offence - further fine up to $2,000/day.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Port Master may direct where vessel to be berthed, moored, anchored in Singapore territorial waters.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 43(a) - Power of Port Master in relation to vessel

regulation_detail: Port Master may direct removal of vessel from one place to another in Singapore territorial waters, specify removal time.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 43(b) - Power of Port Master in relation to vessel

regulation_detail: Port Master may regulate/restrict/prohibit vessel movement in port and approaches.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 43(c) - Power of Port Master in relation to vessel

regulation_detail: Port Master may declare berths, locations, anchorages, fairways for vessel use, prohibited/restricted areas by Gazette notification.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 43(d) - Power of Port Master in relation to vessel

regulation_detail: Port Master may direct owner/agent/master to furnish vessel/cargo info before entering/leaving port.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 44(1) - Owner, agent or master of vessel to report arrival or departure

regulation_detail: Owner/agent/master of vessel arriving in port must report arrival as directed by Port Master.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 44(2)(a) - Owner, agent or master of vessel to report arrival or departure

regulation_detail: Vessel arrival reporting requires providing general declaration of arrival to Port Master within specified time/means.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 44(2)(b)(i) - Owner, agent or master of vessel to report arrival or departure

regulation_detail: Vessel arrival reporting requires providing clearance from last port to Port Master within specified time/means.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 44(2)(b)(ii) - Owner, agent or master of vessel to report arrival or departure

regulation_detail: Vessel arrival reporting requires providing list of passengers on board to Port Master within specified time/means.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 44(2)(b)(iii) - Owner, agent or master of vessel to report arrival or departure

regulation_detail: Vessel arrival reporting requires providing list of crew on board to Port Master within specified time/means.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 44(2)(b)(iv) - Owner, agent or master of vessel to report arrival or departure

regulation_detail: Vessel arrival reporting requires providing cargo manifest for goods to be discharged/transhipped to Port Master within specified time/means.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 44(2)(b)(v) - Owner, agent or master of vessel to report arrival or departure

regulation_detail: Vessel arrival reporting requires providing any other documents required by Port Master.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 44(2)(b)(vi) - Owner, agent or master of vessel to report arrival or departure

regulation_detail: Vessels from non-consular countries must produce certificate of registry and deposit ship’s articles with Director of Marine on arrival.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 44(2)(c) - Owner, agent or master of vessel to report arrival or departure

regulation_detail: Failure to comply with vessel arrival reporting requirements (Section 44) incurs fine up to $10,000.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 44(3) - Owner, agent or master of vessel to report arrival or departure

regulation_detail: Port Master may require owner/master of vessel in transit in port/approaches to provide vessel/cargo/equipment particulars.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 45(1) - Port Master may require vessel in transit in port or approaches to port to provide information

regulation_detail: Failure to comply with Port Master's request for transit vessel information (Section 45(1)) incurs fine up to $10,000.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 45(2) - Port Master may require vessel in transit in port or approaches to port to provide information

regulation_detail: Vessel (non-exempted) must not leave port without obtaining port clearance from Port Master.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 46(1) - No vessel to leave port without port clearance

regulation_detail: Port clearance application requires providing general declaration of departure to Port Master within specified time/means.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 46(2)(a)(i) - No vessel to leave port without port clearance

regulation_detail: Port clearance application requires providing list of crew for departure to Port Master within specified time/means.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 46(2)(a)(ii) - No vessel to leave port without port clearance

regulation_detail: Port clearance application requires providing list of passengers for departure to Port Master within specified time/means.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 46(2)(a)(iii) - No vessel to leave port without port clearance

regulation_detail: Port clearance application requires providing cargo manifest for goods on board and cargo loaded/discharged at port to Port Master.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 46(2)(a)(iv) - No vessel to leave port without port clearance

regulation_detail: Port clearance application requires providing any other documents required by Port Master.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 46(2)(a)(v) - No vessel to leave port without port clearance

regulation_detail: Port clearance application may require producing certificate of registry and other vessel documents for Port Master inspection.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 46(2)(b) - No vessel to leave port without port clearance

regulation_detail: Port clearance requirement (Section 46) does not apply to warships, government vessels (non-commercial).
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 46(3) - No vessel to leave port without port clearance

regulation_detail: Leaving/attempting to leave port without clearance incurs fine up to $10,000 (owner/agent/master/sender involved).
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 46(4) - No vessel to leave port without port clearance

regulation_detail: Vessel attempting to leave port without clearance may be detained (if still in Singapore waters).
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 46(4) - No vessel to leave port without port clearance

regulation_detail: Port clearance not granted if owner/agent/master has not complied with Regulation of Imports and Exports Act.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 46(5)(a) - No vessel to leave port without port clearance

regulation_detail: Port clearance requires owner/agent/master to declare vessel's nationality to Port Master.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 46(5)(b) - No vessel to leave port without port clearance

regulation_detail: Port Master may require production of certificate of registry for port clearance.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 46(5)(b) - No vessel to leave port without port clearance

regulation_detail: Port Master must inscribe declared vessel nationality on port clearance certificate.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 46(5)(b) - No vessel to leave port without port clearance

regulation_detail: Port Master must refuse port clearance for vessels to be detained under Act/written law, may refuse for vessels that may be detained.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 46(6) - No vessel to leave port without port clearance

regulation_detail: Port Master may refuse port clearance for vessels whose owner/master has not complied with/charged with offence under Act/written law.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 46(7) - No vessel to leave port without port clearance

regulation_detail: Port Master may refuse port clearance for vessels anchored in submarine cable corridor without security deposit.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 46(8) - No vessel to leave port without port clearance

regulation_detail: Public telecomm licensee may require vessel owner/agent/master to inspect submarine cable if damage suspected.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 46(9) - No vessel to leave port without port clearance

regulation_detail: Expenses for submarine cable inspection (if required) to be paid by vessel owner/agent/master.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 46(10) - No vessel to leave port without port clearance

regulation_detail: Vessel failing to leave port within 48 hours of port clearance (or shorter period) must return PCC within 6 hours after expiry.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 47(1) - Owner, agent or master of vessel not leaving within 48 hours after port clearance to return port clearance to Port Master

regulation_detail: Fresh port clearance required if vessel does not leave within 48 hours (or shorter period) and if required by Port Master.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 47(1) - Owner, agent or master of vessel not leaving within 48 hours after port clearance to return port clearance to Port Master

regulation_detail: Failure to return port clearance certificate after 48-hour departure delay incurs fine up to $5,000; vessel may be detained.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 47(2) - Owner, agent or master of vessel not leaving within 48 hours after port clearance to return port clearance to Port Master

regulation_detail: Port Master may prohibit vessel from entering Singapore territorial waters if not in public interest.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 48 - Power to prohibit vessel from entering territorial waters

regulation_detail: Port Master may direct vessel to leave Singapore territorial waters if not in public interest to remain.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 49(1) - Power to direct vessel to leave territorial waters

regulation_detail: Vessel operator aggrieved by Port Master's direction to leave territorial waters may appeal to Minister within 7 days.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 49(2) - Power to direct vessel to leave territorial waters

regulation_detail: Authority may take possession and dispose of vessel failing to leave territorial waters as directed (or after refused appeal).
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 49(3) - Power to direct vessel to leave territorial waters

regulation_detail: Disobeying lawful direction under Part 8/regulations incurs fine up to $5,000, continuing offence - further fine up to $500/day.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 50(1) - Penalty for disobedience of direction

regulation_detail: Authority may take necessary actions to carry out/comply with direction if refusal/neglect to comply, regardless of prosecution.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 50(2) - Penalty for disobedience of direction

regulation_detail: Expenses incurred by Authority to enforce direction compliance to be paid by offending person.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 50(3) - Penalty for disobedience of direction

regulation_detail: Authority may remove/alter navigation obstructions in port/approaches (even if lawfully made), with Minister approval and compensation.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 51(1) - Removal of certain obstructions and compensation therefor

regulation_detail: Disputes concerning obstruction removal compensation summarily determined by competent court.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 51(2) - Removal of certain obstructions and compensation therefor

regulation_detail: Appeal against court decision on obstruction removal compensation lies to General Division of High Court.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 51(3) - Removal of certain obstructions and compensation therefor

regulation_detail: Port Master may board vessel on fire in port, give orders for scuttling, removal, other measures for safety.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Port Master may enforce orders (scuttling, removal) if master does not comply with fire on board vessel.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Expenses incurred by Port Master in fire on board vessel response recoverable from vessel master/owner.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Port Master, Authority officer, police officer may board vessel if offense suspected or for duty discharge.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Master refusing entry to Port Master/authorized personnel for boarding incurs fine up to $1,000.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Port Master's orders/directions can be executed by any Authority employee under Port Master's control.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Authorized person executing Port Master's act may call for necessary assistance.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Part 8 (Port Regulations) and regulations do not apply to Singapore Armed Forces vessels (unless expressly stated otherwise).
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 55 - Exemption of vessels belonging to Singapore Armed Forces

regulation_detail: Authority not liable for any act/omission/default of Port Master.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 56 - Indemnity to Authority for act of Port Master

regulation_detail: Authority may declare any area in port to be a pilotage district by Gazette notification.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Declaration of pilotage district must define district limits.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Every vessel navigating in pilotage district must be under pilotage; owner/agent/master must comply.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 60(1) - Authority may require vessel to be under pilotage

regulation_detail: Vessel moved within pilotage district area deemed as navigating in pilotage district (for pilotage compulsion).
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 60(2) - Authority may require vessel to be under pilotage

regulation_detail: Authority may exempt vessel/class of vessels from compulsory pilotage in pilotage district, with conditions.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 60(3) - Authority may require vessel to be under pilotage

regulation_detail: Failure to employ authorized pilot when compulsory pilotage required incurs fine up to $5,000 + double pilotage dues as penalty.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 61 - Failure to employ pilot under certain circumstances

regulation_detail: Authority may employ pilots as necessary for adequate and efficient pilotage service.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 62(1) - Authorised pilot and berthing master

regulation_detail: Authority may authorize persons to pilot vessels in pilotage district, with conditions.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 62(2)(a) - Authorised pilot and berthing master

regulation_detail: Wharf/dock owner may authorize berthing masters (with Authority approval, conditions) for berthing/unberthing/docking at their facility.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 62(2)(b) - Authorised pilot and berthing master

regulation_detail: Vessel must be piloted in pilotage district only by authorized pilot.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 63 - Vessel to be piloted by authorised pilots

regulation_detail: Person not authorized pilot engaging in pilotage act in pilotage district incurs fine up to $5,000.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 64(1) - Penalties as to employment of pilot

regulation_detail: Knowingly employing unauthorized pilot/berthing master in pilotage district incurs fine up to $5,000.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 64(2) - Penalties as to employment of pilot

regulation_detail: Pilot acting beyond license limits/conditions deemed unauthorized pilot.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 64(3) - Penalties as to employment of pilot

regulation_detail: Acting as pilot for vessel in distress in pilotage district is exempt from penalties (for unauthorized pilotage).
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 64(4) - Penalties as to employment of pilot

regulation_detail: Person must possess valid license to be employed as authorized pilot in pilotage district.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996

regulation_detail: Authority must obtain Minister's approval and notify in Gazette to prescribe rates, charges, fees for services/facilities.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 27(1) - Rates, charges, dues, etc., payable to Authority

regulation_detail: Authority may set charges as it thinks fit for services/facilities/goods supplied where no rates/fees prescribed.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 27(2) - Rates, charges, dues, etc., payable to Authority

regulation_detail: Authority may require security for payment of rates, charges, dues, fees, or for other purposes of the Act.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 27(3) - Rates, charges, dues, etc., payable to Authority

regulation_detail: Authority may determine fees for issuance/renewal of licenses/permits under the Act or regulations.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 27(4) - Rates, charges, dues, etc., payable to Authority

regulation_detail: Authority may remit or waive whole/part of rates, charges, dues, fees.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 27(5) - Rates, charges, dues, etc., payable to Authority

regulation_detail: Owner/agent/master of every vessel calling at Singapore must pay maritime welfare fee.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 27(6) - Rates, charges, dues, etc., payable to Authority

regulation_detail: Owner/agent/master of vessel entering/leaving/using/plying port must pay port dues and pilotage dues.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 27(7) - Rates, charges, dues, etc., payable to Authority

regulation_detail: Authority may levy goods dues on goods brought into/out of specified private wharf/premises.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 27(8) - Rates, charges, dues, etc., payable to Authority

regulation_detail: Goods dues payable by owner/occupier of wharf/premises, vehicle/vessel owner carrying goods, or their agent.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 27(9) - Rates, charges, dues, etc., payable to Authority

regulation_detail: Authority may recover goods dues from owner/occupier of wharf/premises, vehicle/vessel owner, or their agent.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 27(10) - Rates, charges, dues, etc., payable to Authority

regulation_detail: Unpaid dues, charges, fees, rates recoverable by Authority in court as simple contract debt.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 27(11) - Rates, charges, dues, etc., payable to Authority

regulation_detail: Maritime welfare fees not payable for warships.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 27(12)(a) - Rates, charges, dues, etc., payable to Authority

regulation_detail: Maritime welfare fees not payable for government vessels (non-commercial service).
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 27(12)(b) - Rates, charges, dues, etc., payable to Authority

regulation_detail: Maritime welfare fees not payable for vessel/class of vessels exempted by Minister.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 27(12)(c) - Rates, charges, dues, etc., payable to Authority

regulation_detail: Authority officer may enter vessel to ascertain rates, charges, dues, fees, and obtain related info.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 28(1) - Power of entry into vessels

regulation_detail: Master failing to comply with authorized officer's info/document request for dues assessment incurs fine up to $5,000, continuing offence - further fine $500/day.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 28(2) - Power of entry into vessels

regulation_detail: Authority may distrain/arrest vessel for non-payment of rates, charges, dues, fees, damages, penalties.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 29(1) - Power to distrain for non-payment of dues, rates, etc.

regulation_detail: Authority may sell distrained/arrested vessel if dues/costs unpaid for 14 days.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 29(2) - Power to distrain for non-payment of dues, rates, etc.

regulation_detail: Proceeds from vessel sale (distraint) used to satisfy unpaid dues/costs.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 29(3) - Power to distrain for non-payment of dues, rates, etc.

regulation_detail: Surplus from vessel sale (after dues/costs) returned to vessel owner on demand (within 1 year).
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 29(4)(a) - Power to distrain for non-payment of dues, rates, etc.

regulation_detail: Unclaimed surplus from vessel sale (after 1 year) paid to Authority funds; owner rights extinguished.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 29(4)(b) - Power to distrain for non-payment of dues, rates, etc.

regulation_detail: Port Master must not grant port clearance if dues/fees outstanding unless paid or security given.
source_document: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore Act 1996
source_section: Section 29(5) - Power to distrain for non-payment of dues, rates, etc.
